review.title: Segregating event streams and noise with a Markov renewal process model
review.abstract: We describe an inference task in which a set of timestamped event observations must be clustered into an unknown number of temporal sequences with independent and varying rates of observations. Various existing approaches to multi-object tracking assume a fixed number of sources and/or a fixed observation rate; we develop an approach to inferring structure in timestamped data produced by a mixture of an unknown and varying number of similar Markov renewal processes, plus independent clutter noise. The inference simultaneously distinguishes signal from noise as well as clustering signal observations into separate source streams. We illustrate the technique via a synthetic experiment as well as an experiment to track a mixture of singing birds.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Different approaches exist for the task of deriving the temporal evolution of multiple sources based on common observations (Mahler, 2007; Van Gael et al., 2008), which are generally based on a model in which sources are continuously observable, in the sense that they are expected to emit / return observations at each step in time (although there may be evidence), but there are different types of sources for which observations are inherently intermittent, and for which this intermittent has temporal structure that can be characterized as a point process. Examples include acoustic event sequences such as birdsong or footsteps (Wang and Brown, 2006), Internet access protocols (Arlitt and Williamson, 1997), pulsars in astronomy (Keane et al., 2010), and neural firing patterns (Bobrowski et al al al al al., 2009). Intermittent observations are often not distributed with the sparse imaging techniques that are only a representation of time.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related Work
sections.text: To our knowledge, this particular problem has not been addressed directly in the literature, but temporal data is most often treated with a model of sources that continuously or synchronously update to an underlying temporal sampling rate. Relevant formulations for our purposes include the infinite factorial hidden Markov model (infinite FHMM) by Van Gael et al. (2008) or the probability hypothesis density filters (PHD filters) (Mahler, 2007), both of which describe an unknown number of independent Markov sources. FHMMs assume that the underlying sources are non-intermittent throughout their lives, and that they persist throughout the observation period. Pragmatically, intermittent emissions can be handled by including standstill states, although the duration of such states cannot assume arbitrary distribution.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments
sections.text: We have described a method of multiple Markov renewal (MMRP) that uses an MRP model, an iid clutter noise model, and a set of time-stamped data points and finds a most likely division of the data into zero or more MRP sequences plus clutter noise. In the following, we will demonstrate their properties using a synthetic experiment (Section 4.2) before applying them to a specific task of tracking multiple singing birds in an audio mix (Section 4.3).

sections.heading: 4.1 Evaluation Measures
sections.text: To evaluate the empirical performance of our inference method, we need to determine whether it can properly separate the signal from the noise, and whether it can correctly separate each individual MRP sequence into its own stream. MMRP inferences can be considered a cluster task, and could be evaluated accordingly. However, the noise cluster differs qualitatively from the MRP clusters, and the transitions within the MRP sequences are the latent features of primary interest, so we focus our weighting yardsticks on signal / noise separation and transitions. sections.heading: 4.3 Birdsong Audio Experiment
sections.text: Many natural sound sources generate signals with structured patterns of emissions and silence, such as birdsong or footsteps. If emissions can be modelled as MRP from such a source, then our follow-up method should be able to separate several simultaneous "streams" of emissions. In the following experiment, we investigated the ability of our conclusion to perform this separation in data derived from audio signals containing several cases of a common bird species in many European countries, the Common Chiffchaffinch (Salomon and Hemim, 1992). Chiffchaffinch song consists of sequences of typical length of 8-20 "syllables." Each syllable is a pitch that consists of a chirping downwards to a short tone in the range of 5-8 kHz. Syllables are separated by about 0.2-0.3 seconds. To our knowledge, the exact tone sequence has not been studied in detail; it appears to be a short-term dependence and therefore to be analysed in the margins.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced a specific cluster problem, namely the separation of time-stamped data derived from multi-point processes and confusing noise. We have developed an approach to derive structure from data generated by a mixture of an unknown number of similar Markov renewal processes (MRPs) and independent noise. In a synthetic experiment, we have shown that inference can work very well even under high noise conditions (up to − 24 dB SNR). In an experiment with birdsong audio data, we have also shown strong performance, although dependent on the quality of the underlying representation, to restore events from audio data. Our method is general and has very few free parameters. The conclusion in the present work is limited to models without a hidden state and with only uniform Markov dependence. These limitations result from the comparative models, which are in contrast to the previous models in the MMRP class.
